docs.lead_paragraph: They've crowded into stuffy rallies at a Seattle union hall, protested in front of fast food restaurants, marched down city streets and implored city leaders to demand an immediate $15 an hour minimum wage hike for all employees.

headline.main: Seattle Aims to Lead Nation to $15 Minimum Wage
headline.print_headline: Seattle Aims to Lead Nation to $15 Minimum Wage

docs.snippet: They've crowded into stuffy rallies at a Seattle union hall, protested in front of fast food restaurants, marched down city streets and implored city leaders to demand an immediate $15 an hour minimum wage hike for all employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Valuing knowledge and experience, some employers are making extra efforts to encourage longtime workers to stay.

headline.main: The Age Premium: Retaining Older Workers

docs.abstract: Some employers are making extra efforts of retaining their longtime workers, recognizing value of their knowledge, experience, rapport with customers and ability to mentor younger workers; CVS Caremark, Michelin, and the National Institutes of Health are examples of such employers; efforts coincides with trends of increasingly older customer population and fact that more Americans are working later in life.
docs.snippet: Valuing knowledge and experience, some employers are making extra efforts to encourage longtime workers to stay.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many big events now happen later in adulthood, so it is not too surprising that saving for retirement is increasingly put off. But for people on the cusp of 40, it is time to do something.

headline.main: Playing Catch-Up While Retirement Remains Far Off
headline.print_headline: Playing Catch-Up While Retirement Remains Far Off

docs.abstract: Financial experts say there are a variety of ways for people between the ages of 34 to 49 to save a considerable amount for retirement if they have not already begun to do so.
docs.snippet: Many big events now happen later in adulthood, so it is not too surprising that saving for retirement is increasingly put off. But for people on the cusp of 40, it is time to do something.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether you begin collecting payments at 62 or 70, the best choice depends on your financial situation.

headline.main: Social Security at 62? Let’s Run the Numbers
headline.print_headline: Social Security at 62? Let’s Run the Numbers

docs.abstract: Many financial planners advise that retirees wait as long as possible before receiving Social Security benefits; despite this advice, sizable number of Americans who reach age 62 apply for benefits immediately, which locks in the lowest possible payment for life; waiting makes sense for those who do not immediately need the money, particularly in light of longer life spans.
docs.snippet: Whether you begin collecting payments at 62 or 70, the best choice depends on your financial situation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The relatively few Americans who move to Canada often find that they enjoy the country’s more liberal policies and free health care, though there are adjustments to make.

headline.main: The Trade-Offs of Relocating North to Canada
headline.print_headline: The Trade-Offs of Relocating North to Canada

docs.abstract: Relatively small number of Americans who choose to move to Canada to retire are drawn by several factors, including country's more liberal social and economic policies, as well as affordable real estate and spectacular landscapes.
docs.snippet: The relatively few Americans who move to Canada often find that they enjoy the country’s more liberal policies and free health care, though there are adjustments to make.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many are trading traditional homes for lives of mobility, freedom and spontaneity.

headline.main: R.V. Life: Getting Kicks at Age 66
headline.print_headline: R.V. Life: Getting Kicks at Age 66

docs.abstract: Number of retirees who are taking to open road and living and traveling in recreational vehicles is growing; RV landscape has changed considerably in last decade because of new technologies and active lifestyle embraced by baby boomers.
docs.snippet: Many are trading traditional homes for lives of mobility, freedom and spontaneity.

docs.lead_paragraph: “Under My Skin,” a body-swapping comedy at the Little Shubert Theater, may bring on flashbacks from your cinematic past, circa the Reagan administration.

headline.seo: ‘Under My Skin,’ a Comedy at the Little Shubert Theater
headline.main: Good to Be Alive Again, but What’s This Body?
headline.print_headline: Good to Be Alive Again, but What’s This Body?

docs.abstract: Laura Collins-Hughes reviews Robert Sternin and Prudence Fraser play Under My Skin, directed by Kirsten Sanderson at the Little Shubert Theater; Matt Walton and Kerry Butler star.
docs.snippet: “Under My Skin,” a body-swapping comedy at the Little Shubert Theater, may bring on flashbacks from your cinematic past, circa the Reagan administration.

docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey were invited to speak at the annual fiscal summit meeting by the Peterson Foundation, where budget talks made brief appearances.

headline.main: Budget Agenda Plays Second Fiddle at Fiscal Forum
headline.print_headline: Budget Agenda Plays Second Fiddle at Fiscal Forum

docs.abstract: Former Pres Bill Clinton and New Jersey Gov Chris Christie are invited to speak at annual fiscal summit meeting by the Peterson Foundation; talk often veers far from budget talks, as main news is politics; Christie responds with a quick 'yes' when asked whether he was considering running for president.
docs.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey were invited to speak at the annual fiscal summit meeting by the Peterson Foundation, where budget talks made brief appearances.

keywords.value: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the nominee for secretary of health and human services, was called “a force for bringing people together” at her Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday.

headline.main: Another Breezy Hearing for Obama Health Pick
headline.print_headline: Another Breezy Hearing for Obama Health Pick

docs.abstract: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, Pres Obama's nominee for secretary of health and human services, appears to be on swift path to confirmation after she sails through another cordial Senate hearing without promising significant changes in federal health policy or regulations.
docs.snippet: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the nominee for secretary of health and human services, was called “a force for bringing people together” at her Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday.
